title: German defense minister pushes for international ‘security zone’ in Syria
text:
German Defense Minister Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer | Alex Wong/Getty Images German defense minister pushes for international ‘security zone’ in Syria Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer said she would discuss the plan with NATO partners this week.

BERLIN — Germany's defense minister has made a surprise proposal for an internationally controlled "security zone" in northern Syria to stabilize the region.

Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, who also serves as leader of Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democrats (CDU), said late on Monday that she would discuss her plan with NATO partners at a meeting in Brussels this week.

She told the broadcaster Deutsche Welle that Germany could no longer merely be a "spectator" in Syria, saying: "My recommendation is that we establish an internationally controlled security zone in cooperation with Turkey and Russia."

Kramp-Karrenbauer continued: "This security zone would seek to resume the fight against terror and against the Islamic State, which has currently come to a standstill. It would also ensure that we stabilize the region so that rebuilding civilian life is once again possible, and so that those who have fled can also return voluntarily."

She did not offer more detail on how such a zone would be secured and whether German troops would be involved. The German parliament would have to approve such a deployment.

"My recommendation is that we establish an internationally controlled security zone in cooperation with Turkey and Russia." — German Defense Minister Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer

Northeastern Syria, previously one of the war-torn country's most stable regions, has become a battleground after Turkey launched a military operation aimed at driving Syrian Kurdish fighters away from the border.

Amid the fighting, several hundred Islamic State members reportedly escaped from Kurdish custody. More than 100,000 people have become displaced since the start of Turkey's incursion, according to the United Nations.

A controversial ceasefire, announced by the United States last week, is due to expire on Tuesday evening. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan will meet with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin in Sochi Tuesday afternoon.

Kramp-Karrenbauer's comments mark the first time Germany has proposed a military initiative in the Middle East.

Yet while her announcement was reportedly coordinated with Merkel, it had apparently not been discussed with the CDU's coalition partners, the Social Democrats (SPD), prompting some disquiet within their ranks.

In another interview with public broadcaster ZDF on Monday, Kramp-Karrenbauer said she had informed Foreign Minister Heiko Maas, a Social Democrat, via text message that she would "come up with a proposal." The foreign ministry on Tuesday told the German press agency DPA it saw a need for further discussion.

Social Democrat lawmaker and defense expert Fritz Felgentreu told Deutschlandfunk radio on Tuesday the plan had not been discussed with the SPD at all and that he had "a lot of questions in that context," adding: "That we're skeptical is obvious."

Der Spiegel reported that Kramp-Karrenbauer's push had also taken the CDU's Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union, by surprise.

Criticism also came from the opposition, with Greens lawmaker Omid Nouripour saying: "The fear of refugees seems to have obscured the view of reality in parts of the CDU." He added that the proposal would "reinforce Erdoğan's impression that he can blackmail us with refugees."

Erdoğan, who says Ankara wants to resettle some of the 3.5 million Syrians currently living in Turkey in a "safe zone" in northern Syria, frequently threatens to "open the floodgates" and send refugees to Europe. The Turkish safe zone proposal has been criticized by humanitarian organisations.

Michael Link, a lawmaker from the pro-business Free Democrats (FDP) said that Kramp-Karrenbauer's announcement had been "clumsy," adding: "The proposal hasn't been mentioned to their own coalition partner. One doesn't win approval in Europe if the first stumbling block lies in Berlin and the coalition partner doesn't go along."

Praise for Kramp-Karrenbauer's proposal came from the Kurdish Community in Germany, an umbrella organization, which wrote on Twitter: "Germany must take responsibility. It's right for [Kramp-Karrenbauer] to take initiative within NATO."

Norbert Röttgen, chair of the Bundestag's foreign affairs committee, told POLITICO that if nothing changed regarding Europe's "paralysis" over Syria, "the total foreign policy failure of Europe will continue and quickly expand into a genuine crisis of legitimacy of the EU."

He added: "Europe must act in regards to foreign and security policy, as we realize that others — the U.S., Russia or also Iran — do not act in our interest."

Additional reporting by Hans von der Burchard and Joshua Posaner. This article was updated.
description: Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer said she would discuss the plan with NATO partners this week.
